awd_titl_txt: Asymptotic Representation Theory, Enumeration, and Combinatorial Probability
awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns problems from several areas of pure mathematics such as number theory, the study of the integers and their properties; representation theory, the study of symmetry; and probability theory, the mathematical study of randomness. These problems appear to have little in common with each other, nor do they seem to have any obvious applications, and yet a deeper look reveals many subtle connections between them and possible applications to other areas of applied and theoretical science. For example, the question "how many alternating sign matrices of order N exist?" which was asked by mathematicians in the 1980s in connection with an obscure algorithm proposed by the logician Charles Dodgson (aka Lewis Carroll) in the 19th century turned out to have connections to "square ice," an exotic form of water ice that was detected experimentally a few years ago by British researchers. Similarly, the Witten zeta function, which the investigator plans to study in connection with the enumeration of certain types of symmetry, was previously studied by other researchers (including the physicist Edward Witten) in a different context related to problems in quantum field theory. It is these sorts of connections that the investigator hopes to shed light on through his research, and which make pure mathematics such a fruitful area of study for the advancement of human knowledge.

The specific problems the investigator proposes to study are questions at the interface of enumerative, algebraic and asymptotic combinatorics, with connections to other branches of mathematics, notably representation theory, probability theory, asymptotic analysis, and number theory. For example, one problem involves a new direction in asymptotic representation theory, namely that of finding asymptotic formulas for the number of n-dimensional representations of a Lie group as n grows large. The investigator's recent paper solved this problem for the group SU(3) using a difficult analysis of the so-called Witten zeta function associated with the group, which highlighted some intriguing connections between the problem and seemingly unrelated questions in analytic number theory and the theory of modular forms. In an additional part of the project, the investigator proposes to author a monograph on alternating sign matrices, which have been the subject of great interest since their discovery in the 1980s and are related to many contemporary research topics in combinatorics, probability theory and statistical physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research component of this project consisted of a set of activities centered on addressing open problems in pure mathematics in the areas of analytic and enumerative combinatorics, representation theory, probability theory and related areas. The PI and his participating graduate student obtained significant results in those areas.

Among the key outcomes was a paper studying the Riemann xi function, a well-studied mathematical object related to the Riemann zeta function, the subject of the famous Riemann Hypothesis (RH), known as one of the most important open problems in mathematics. Motivated by RH and related questions, the PI studied certain ways to represent the Riemann xi function as infinite series related to systems of orthogonal polynomials. These representations turn out to have subtle and very interesting properties, which may eventually help shed light on still poorly understood aspects of the Riemann xi and zeta functions.

Another direction we investigated was the oriented swap process, a stochastic model for sorting studied in previous work by the PI and others. In a series of several new papers, the PI and his collaborators solved an open problem posed by the PI in his 2008 paper, exposing new and subtle connections between the oriented swap process, other well-studied stochastic models such as last passage percolation, and asymptotic phenomena in random matrix theory.

The PI's work led to several additional papers that were published in peer-reviewed journals, and disseminated to the scientific community via online distribution, talks at conferences and seminars, and informal discussions with colleagues. The PI also worked on a textbook on complex analysis aimed at graduate students, and has a draft manuscript in advanced stages of preparation.

The PI's then-graduate student Robert Scherer also derived several results which he published in peer-reviewed journals and which formed a part of his PhD dissertation, submitted and approved in early 2021. His most important outcome was the proof of a conjecture in analytic combinatorics posed by Greg Kuperberg in a paper from 1996. Dr. Scherer's solution established that a certain sequence of integers arising in the asymptotic representation theory of the exceptional Lie group G_2 grows asymptotically with a certain speed predicted by Kuperberg. Moreover, Scherer identified that a numerical constant appearing in Kuperberg's formula for the growth speed has the precise value 5*pi/(8575*pi - 15552 sqrt(3)) — a surprising and elegant result that will be of great interest to other researchers studying this integer sequence and related phenomena in asymptotic representation theory. Scherer's proof required him to develop delicate new techniques of complex analysis and asymptotic analysis, extending the theory of analytic combinatorics in new directions that are likely to be useful to other researchers in the field.

The project also included outreach and mentoring activities. The PI worked mentored a UC Davis undergraduate student on a research project that included the creation of research software to study and demonstrate the moving sofa problem. The PI continued to develop online resources that make topics in mathematics accessible to a wide non-expert audience. In addition to his existing web article and image gallery on the moving sofa problem, in a recent collaboration with UK-based Futurum Careers magazine he created an expository article aimed at high school students on the subject of the Tower of Hanoi puzzle. The Tower of Hanoi is a popular mechanical puzzle that has connections to advanced topics in mathematics and computer science, and the PI's new article, combined with computer animations he generated and makes available via his website, aims to highlight those connections. The magazine issue containing the article is distributed to teachers in the UK, US and elsewhere along with a companion worksheet, and is available as a free online resource under an open access license. The PI hopes that these resources will inspire students to pursue careers in mathematics and other STEM areas.
